So far, all I have seen on this forum is each side claiming the other side is a) stupid or b) lying. I would like to ask an actual question.
 
 I assume that the Creationists here do not dispute science altogether. But tell me where you draw the line. 
 
 Is physics for real? 400 years ago, Galileo was condemned for teaching that the Earth goes around the sun, while the Church claimed that this contradicted Scripture. The Church has recently apologized. Does anybody here think they were wrong to do so?
 
 What other parts of physics do Creationists reject? The Big Bang, obviously. Is anybody here a Young Earth Creationist, rejecting geology, archeology, radioactive dating, astrophysics, and a good deal more? Are there any problems with General Relativity or Quantum Mechanics?
 
 How about math? Does anybody still think that the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter is exactly 3, instead of the mathematical value of pi, approximately 3.1415926535...
 
 How about chemistry? Any problems there?
 
 Biology next. Do you deny the genetic code? The existence of mutations? The creation of novel varieties of plants and animals through breeding and selection? Genetic engineering? The rapid appearance of drug-resistant bacteria, when all the non-resistant ones are killed off? The change in butterfly colors when England was burning soft coal, and the change back when they stopped?
 
 I expect that different individuals will have different answers, just as there are numerous Christians who accept evolution and the Big Bang, while believing that God is behind it all in one way or another.

Likewise I do not deny the genetic code, I just deny it could have been built up the way darwinists say.

 The YEC only decide certain aspects of science are wrong. It just so happens the aspects they disagree with are solely those that contradict their religion. If it jibes with the religion they have no problem. That sounds like they are not disagreeing with science for scientific reasons.

Many YECs reject a constant speed of light, because they think that a faster speed of light earlier in history could speed up radiometric decay, which could therefore account for old radiometric dates.
 
 (The problem that accelerated radiometric decay means a huge heat output that would have parboiled Noah is usually ignored.)
 
 Some of them postulate that starlight was created "on route", in order to explain how we are seeing light from stars that are more than 6000 light-years away.
 
 The 'hydraulic and ecologic sorting" that they sometimes refer to as an explanation for the sorting of fossils into different levels in the geological record (which they suggest was deposited during Noah's Flood) is unlike any hydraulic sorting known to people who study the subject. Among other problems, whole dinosaurs and disarticulated dinosaur bones have to end up in the same layers. Insects in lumps of amber have to be sorted by the nature of the insect inside the amber, as opposed to being sorted by the size, shape, and weight of the piece of amber that enclosed the insect prior to its transportation and burial.
 
 They have to ignore standard heat calculations to permit the "water canopy" to fall without heating up, and to permit the oceans to open, the continents to rift apart, and the basaltic ocean floors to crystallize from a magma, all without boiling the oceans under poor Noah.

Wells: Many YECs reject a constant speed of light, because they think that a faster speed of light earlier in history could speed up radiometric decay, which could therefore account for old radiometric dates.
 
 That's not the only explanation.....(though I think a plausible one).....There's actually a very simple explanation for the starlight problem. Follow closely:
 
 When the universe was created, according to the big bang theory, everything started out in a very dense state and then explanded outwards. Now let's picture a balloon...(which acts as the universe) Now draw a black dot on that balloon...(this will represent the earth). Now, near that black dot, draw a red dot on the ballon..(this represents a star.) With me?
 
 Ok...now it's time to fill the balloon (the universe) at a high rate. Suddenly the space between the black and the red dots quickly increases as the balloon grows larger. Still with me?
 
 Ok...so we have the black dot (earth) and the red dot (stars), which were both created at the same time....and at first the stars and earth were much, much closer than they are now. Only from expansion have we separated. But the thing is, the starlight, which began at the moment of creation (and originally had far less distance to travel), had the benefit of its regular speed (whatever that was at the time) PLUS the expansion........So in otherwords, the speed of light is actually "sped up" exponentially by way of the extremely rapid expansion. So in a way, the light begins to "fill in the gaps" so to say, as the universe expands. 
 
 Consequently, the light that we see today is probably light that was "stretched to us" ....it is not light that travelled to us all the way from a star untold lightyears away. It's in this way that the starlight problem is fixed. :)

need I dig up the link that shows you how the molecule is degraded by the mutation? 

 
 Degraded is not an applicable term. What happens is a single amino acid is replaced by another resulting in a change in hydrophobicity which leads under low oxygen conditions to hemoglobin dimers. Degraded is a value judgement on your part and a meaningless one. What is not meaningless is the reduction in suspecptibility to Malaria due to that same change.

Initially there was no light of course. Photons could not exist under those conditions. And at one stage the universe was opaque. Finally of course there was no earth or milky galaxy till much much later. The light could not be "stretched" to us because there was no place to stretech it to!

 Ah but it might have been different when the universe was young. However I have seen estimates that the expansion rate had to fall below the speed of light by about 380,000 years:\
 
 To wit from WIKI:
 
 
The earliest phases of the Big Bang are subject to much speculation. In the most common models, the universe was filled homogeneously and isotropically with an incredibly high energy density, huge temperatures and pressures, and was very rapidly expanding and cooling. Approximately 10−35 seconds into the expansion, a phase transition caused a cosmic inflation, during which the universe grew exponentially.[22] After inflation stopped, the universe consisted of a quark-gluon plasma, as well as all other elementary particles.[23] Temperatures were so high that the random motions of particles were at relativistic speeds, and particle-antiparticle pairs of all kinds were being continuously created and destroyed in collisions. At some point an unknown reaction called baryogenesis violated the conservation of baryon number, leading to a very small excess of quarks and leptons over antiquarks and anti-leptons-of the order of 1 part in 30 million. This resulted in the predominance of matter over antimatter in the present universe.[24]
 
 The universe continued to grow in size and fall in temperature (and hence the typical energy of each particle was decreasing). Symmetry breaking phase transitions put the fundamental forces of physics and the parameters of elementary particles into their present form.[25] After about 10−11 seconds, the picture becomes less speculative, since particle energies drop to values that can be attained in particle physics experiments. At about 10−6 seconds, quarks and gluons combined to form baryons such as protons and neutrons. The small excess of quarks over antiquarks led to a small excess of baryons over antibaryons. The temperature was now no longer high enough to create new proton-antiproton pairs (similarly for neutrons-antineutrons), so a mass annihilation immediately followed, leaving just one in 1010 of the original protons and neutrons, and none of their antiparticles. A similar process happened at about 1 second for electrons and positrons. After these annihilations, the remaining protons, neutrons and electrons were no longer moving relativistically and the energy density of the universe was dominated by photons (with a minor contribution from neutrinos).
 
 A few minutes into the expansion, when the temperature was about a billion Kelvin and the density was about that of air, neutrons combined with protons to form the universe's deuterium and helium nuclei in a process called Big Bang nucleosynthesis.[26] Most protons remained uncombined as hydrogen nuclei. As the universe cooled, the rest mass energy density of matter came to gravitationally dominate that of the photon radiation. After about 380,000 years the electrons and nuclei combined into atoms (mostly hydrogen); hence the radiation decoupled from matter and continued through space largely unimpeded. This relic radiation is known as the cosmic microwave background radiation.[27]
 
 

 
 So if there was any possible stretching it could only alter the estimates from the CBR by some 380K years. Not much up against the 12-14 billion years for the age of the whole shebang.
The stuff of which dreams are made. ;)

Originally Posted by Antibogotes
 So far, all I have seen on this forum is each side claiming the other side is a) stupid or b) lying. I would like to ask an actual question.
 
 
That's not entirely fair. Most of the time if someone asks an intelligent question and actually reads the response they're treated with respect. I think the reason you've got the impression you have is that SS and WW do a lot of the posting, and they don't actually respond to or learn from anything that is posted.  Excellent. I'll admit that I had only read a few threads. I'll go see about some of these others.

You're also asking if we reject physics? Physics is not a precise, definable science...so there's nothing to accept or reject -- it's all an interpretation or an opinion

 
 I don't recognize this version of physics, and I don't know where to begin to ask you to explain it. I'm going to take a stab in the dark, and begin with my notion of definable science. In physics, there are a number of foundational theories, including Newton's version of mechanics and gravity; the corpuscular and wave theories of light; Clerk-Maxwell's theory of electromagnetism; the luminiferous ether; statistical mechanics; thermodynamics; Special Relativity; General Relativity; Quantum Mechanics; The Standard Model; Quantum Supergravity; String Theory. That's not all, but it is sufficient for our discussion. Some of these theories are still held, some have been completely discarded, and some are currently in question at the margins. For example, General Relativity and Quantum Mechanics are fundamentally incompatible at the energies (=temperatures) of the Big Bang or the core of a Black Hole.
 
 All of this, to me, is quite well-defined in several ways. Each theory can be clearly stated. The main evidence for and against each theory can be clearly stated. The history of each theory is well known. The history of physics, in the sense of which combination of theories is generally accepted, is also known. There are some notable errors and unprofitable side paths along the way, and there are brief transitions when the acceptance of one idea is going down, while another is rising to supplant it. 
 
 You have something else in mind. Please tell me what it is.

Which is to say, yes, he rejects physics. Anything that disagrees with his preconceived notions of what ought to be true is opinion at best, idiocy if he's feeling cranky.

 
 I don't wish to be rude about this, but I asked them what they think, not what you think they think. You're trying to be too helpful.
 
 "When I want to hear your opinion, I'll tell it to youse!"--Any mob boss, any totalitarian, some churches

Initially there was no light of course. Photons could not exist under those conditions. And at one stage the universe was opaque. Finally of course there was no earth or milky galaxy till much much later. The light could not be "stretched" to us because there was no place to stretech it to!

 
 "No light, of course." False, according to the Standard Model and every other physics model I am aware of.
 
 "Photons could not exist under those conditions." What conditions? Why not? According to classical thermodynamics and the Standard model, at high temperature all normal matter emits light, and at those high temperatures again light of sufficient energy turns into every kind of particle, which then gives off more light.
 
 "And at one stage the universe was opaque." According to the same theories, the atoms on the inside of opaque objects emit photons continuously, but they are absorbed by nearby atoms and do not escape. Similarly in the hot, dense, opaque early universe.
 
 "Finally of course there was no earth or milky galaxy till much much later." Correct, though I don't see what that has to do with anything.
 
 "The light could not be "stretched" to us because there was no place to stretech it to!" It didn't need a space to be stretched "to", just room to stretch "in". It has taken billions of years to redshift the cosmic background radiation by a factor of about a thousand. The redshifting went on the entire time, very, very slowly. (Expanding by something like a factor of the 13 billionth root of 1000, or 1.00000000053, each year). At any moment, the space between crests of the wave was getting larger, so they got farther apart while going at the same speed.

post_info.post_title: As a physicist, he's not even a good chemist

ridiculous. Do we accept the genetic code? The existence of mutations? C'mmon. The question is not whether these exist, it's if the given mechanism given by darwinists is scientifically valid. I've asked repeatedly for an example of a mutation that beneficially alters phenotype and have yet to receive one. I don't deny mutations....I deny they play the role evos say they do. Likewise I do not deny the genetic code, I just deny it could have been built up the way darwinists say.
 
 You're also asking if we reject physics? Physics is not a precise, definable science...so there's nothing to accept or reject -- it's all an interpretation or an opinion....Likewise, life is not precise or definable. The big bang is not a scientific fact -- it's simply an interpretation of the available evidence...but some people read the evidence in a completely different way and ackowledge that the big bang has some big holes in it. I don't accept ToE because I don't believe life is inherently accidental....and I don't believe variation arises randomly. Likewise there is no scientifically-proven cases of selection. Likewise there is no evidence in the fossil record of slow, gradual evolution from one species to another -- which has been the story for the past century. Likewise there are no half-ape/half-humans unearthed. Likewise there is no materialistic origin of life. I'll stop there, I guess.

 
 Plenty of YECs reject far more science than you do. Would you really prefer that I make unwarranted assumptions about what you believe? Are you actually offended that I asked politely? I would like to know what you personally believe, and not continue this pointless argument against strawmen.
 
 You say "I don't accept ToE because I don't believe life is inherently accidental." Which accidents? The Big Bang? The current laws of physics? The arbitrary happenstance of which planet life originated on? Or the chance mutations that are part of evolutionary theory?
 
 I'm going to make another stab in the dark, and answer just the last question. ToE says that there are two forces in evolution: random mutation, and natural selection. So nothing arises only from random mutation. Mutations are also not just point mutations, with one base pair substituted for another. Genes can be swapped, duplicated, scrambled, and up- or down-regulated. Whole chromosomes can be duplicated or copied even more times, split into two separate chromosomes, or lost entirely.
 
 Nor does natural selection only act on individual random mutations. Every individual above the level of a single cell has a unique genome, combining expressed and unexpressed genes with and without random variations. Natural selection is simply the fact that some of these combinations are more beneficial than others in some circumstances. 
 
 If there is a drought for several years, the more drought-tolerant plants become more common, and the ones that are overstressed by drought die out. Then if there is excess rain for several years, the ones that do better with more water increase in population percentage. This can be observed in subsistence agriculture using land-race corn, for example, as opposed to industrial monoculture where all the seeds are identical. It is also observed in wild grasses.
 
 Do you accept this so far? If not, which individual bits do you not believe? If so, where do you stop? Somewhere between here and the evolution of the eye, the wing, the flagellum? Be specific.

Ah but it might have been different when the universe was young. However I have seen estimates that the expansion rate had to fall below the speed of light by about 380,000 years:
 
 So if there was any possible stretching it could only alter the estimates from the CBR by some 380K years. Not much up against the 12-14 billion years for the age of the whole shebang.

 
 Sorry, Chem99 1/4. That makes absolutely no sense. The expansion rate is measured by the Hubble "Constant" (something like 70 km/sec-megaparsec, with a very, very slow rate of change), which is not a velocity. It is a fractional change in distance per time period, not a distance per time period. So stars one million parsecs from us (3,200,000 light-years) would be moving away at 70 km/sec. Stars 4 billion parsecs from us would have their distance from us increase at nearly the speed of light, very nearly 300,000 km/sec.
 
 Now we think that it is possible for two points to be outside each other's Hubble volumes, at a bit more than 4 billion parsecs distance, meaning that the distance between them grows by more than one light-year per year. A photon starting out at one and moving at the speed of light toward the other never gets any nearer, so we obviously cannot see such an object, even if we could wait billions of years for the light that is leaving now. But that has nothing to do with the rate of stretching of light since the CBR broke free at a redshift of about 1000.
 
 Or are you thinking of the epoch of Inflation, which was well within the first second after the Big Bang? At that time the rate of expansion was much greater than the Hubble Constant, so that points within each other's Hubble volume before Inflation wound up outside each other's Hubble volume afterwards. But they didn't move apart. The space between them just got bigger.

ToE says that there are two forces in evolution: random mutation, and natural selection.

 
 Just a technical point. Evolutionary theory does not require that mutations should be random. Molecular geneticists are well aware that some genes in some organisms mutate more often than others; alternatively, some genes are conserved more strongly than others. It's just that hotspots apart, there is no evidence for result-orientated directed mutation of genes. Within certain constraints, they appear to be random, but evolutionary theory as such doesn't demand that they should be.
 
 Second, natural selection through competition for resources isn't the only force constraining evolution (though it is the major explanation of adaptation). There is also genetic drift which can distribute neutral mutations through populations, and there are probably also other factors such as structural constraints and canalisation affecting which mutations can see the light of day (i.e. get exposed to natural selection) and which will not.

That too. Still, one could look at any rearrangement or duplication of a genome as a mutation if one's definition were broad enough, but if some want to be narrower in definition, it's fine with moi. Another interesting factor in evolution is symbiosis, though again that would take appropriate genomic rearrangements on the part of both partners to make it work smoothly. I was really arguing that reducing any theory of evolution to two factors, random mutation and natural selection, is to do it serious injustice and in essence tie both hands behind one's back against evolution deniers. :)

"The light could not be "stretched" to us because there was no place to stretech it to!" It didn't need a space to be stretched "to", just room to stretch "in".

 
 What light are we talking about? Starlight? The Universe didn't pop into existence complete with stars...

What light are we talking about? Starlight? The Universe didn't pop into existence complete with stars...

 
 Everything which has a temperature, which is to say everything, radiates light. Right now you're giving off light in the infrared range. Really hot things can glow in the x-ray or gamma ray range, really cold things radiate in the microwave or radio wave range.

Everything which has a temperature, which is to say everything, radiates light. Right now you're giving off light in the infrared range. Really hot things can glow in the x-ray or gamma ray range, really cold things radiate in the microwave or radio wave range.

 
 Absolutely. I saw the words 'redshift' and 'stretched light' and assumed we were talking about starlight...which, of course wouldn't make sense as the Universe would have been pretty spacious by the time stars formed.
 
 I shall read more thoroughly in future (or at least if I'm not suffering from the excesses of the night before!)

I, as a creationist, do not believe in any of the five evolutionary theories:
 
 Cosmic Evolution: the origin of time, space, and matter, i.e. the Big Bang
 Chemical Evolution: the origin of higher elements from hydrogen
 Stellar and Planetary Evolution: origin of stars and planets
 Organic Evolution: the origin of life
 Macro-Evolution: changing from one kind of animal into another
 
 There is a sixth evolutionary theory, but it has been proved in a controlled environment, and it is called micro-evolution (variations within kinds)

Cosmic Evolution: the origin of time, space, and matter, i.e. the Big Bang

 
 Well it came from somewhere and presumably changed as it went along. 
 
 
Chemical Evolution: the origin of higher elements from hydrogen

 
 Careful there that ones been clearly shown to be the case - in a laboratory environment to boot. Not to mention in the form of a hydrogen bomb!
 
 
Stellar and Planetary Evolution: origin of stars and planets

 
 You mean that the planets and stars have always existed? Really - so how come we see stars being made in nurseries via the Hubble telescope.
 
 
Organic Evolution: the origin of life

 
 So you don't believe that life had an origin! WOW so you think its always been present on the Earth? Not even the bible goes that far! And you fail to account for the observation that there IS life.
 
 
Macro-Evolution: changing from one kind of animal into another

 
 Thats not an evolutionary theory, at least not a scientific one. Kinds is a theological construct not a biological one and MOST creationists use the KINDS thing as a support for their arguments.
